Java.what is java: Java is a high-level, object-oriented programming language used for building platform-independent applications via the Java Virtual Machine (JVM).
Java.what is jvm: JVM (Java Virtual Machine) runs Java bytecode and provides platform independence by translating it into machine code at runtime.
Java.what is jdk: JDK (Java Development Kit) is a software development kit for Java, including the compiler, debugger, and runtime environment.
Java.what is jre: JRE (Java Runtime Environment) provides the libraries, Java Virtual Machine, and other components to run Java applications.
Java.what are java data types: Java data types include primitive types (int, long, float, double, char, boolean, byte, short) and reference types (arrays, objects).
Java.what is java variable: A variable is a container to store data, which can be primitive or reference type, and must be declared with a type.
Java.what is java class: A class is a blueprint in Java to create objects, encapsulating data (fields) and behavior (methods).
Java.what is java object: An object is an instance of a class containing attributes and methods defined by the class.
Java.what is java constructor: A constructor initializes an object when it is created. It has the same name as the class and no return type.
Java.what is method in java: A method is a block of code that performs a specific task and can be invoked on an object or class.
Java.what is static keyword: Static keyword declares class-level members that belong to the class rather than any object instance.
Java.what is instance variable: Instance variables belong to individual objects and store object-specific data.
Java.what is local variable: Local variables are declared inside methods or blocks and exist only during execution of that block.
Java.what is java inheritance: Inheritance allows a class to acquire fields and methods of another class using the 'extends' keyword.
Java.what is java interface: An interface is a blueprint of abstract methods that a class can implement, supporting multiple inheritance.
Java.what is java abstract class: Abstract class may contain abstract methods and concrete methods; it cannot be instantiated directly.
Java.what is java method overloading: Method overloading allows multiple methods with the same name but different parameters in the same class.
Java.what is java method overriding: Method overriding allows a subclass to provide a specific implementation of a method declared in the superclass.
Java.what is java polymorphism: Polymorphism allows objects to be treated as instances of their parent class, supporting method overriding and dynamic behavior.
Java.what is java encapsulation: Encapsulation hides internal state and allows controlled access through getters and setters.
Java.what is java abstraction: Abstraction hides implementation details and exposes only necessary functionality to the user.
Java.what is java interface vs abstract class: Interfaces declare methods without implementation, support multiple inheritance; abstract classes can have concrete methods and fields, and support single inheritance.
Java.what is java final keyword: Final prevents modification: final variable cannot change, final method cannot override, final class cannot inherit.
Java.what is java super keyword: Super references the parent class object, used to call parent methods, constructors, or access variables.
Java.what is java this keyword: This refers to the current object instance, used to access fields, methods, or constructors.
Java.what is java constructor chaining: Constructor chaining calls one constructor from another using 'this()' or 'super()' to reuse initialization code.
Java.what is java packages: Packages group related classes and interfaces, providing modularity and namespace management.
Java.what is java import statement: Import allows access to classes or packages from other packages in Java programs.
Java.what is java exception handling: Exception handling manages runtime errors using try, catch, finally, throw, and throws keywords.
Java.what is java try block: Try block contains code that may throw an exception, followed by catch blocks for handling.
Java.what is java catch block: Catch block handles exceptions thrown in the corresponding try block.
Java.what is java finally block: Finally block executes regardless of exception occurrence, often used for cleanup.
Java.what is java throw keyword: Throw explicitly signals an exception in the program.
Java.what is java throws keyword: Throws declares the exceptions a method may propagate to the caller.
Java.what is java checked exception: Checked exceptions are verified at compile-time, requiring explicit handling or declaration.
Java.what is java unchecked exception: Unchecked exceptions occur at runtime and do not require explicit handling, e.g., NullPointerException.
Java.what is java array: An array is a fixed-size collection of elements of the same type, accessible via index.
Java.what is java arraylist: ArrayList is a resizable array from the Java Collections Framework, allowing dynamic addition and removal of elements.
Java.what is java linkedlist: LinkedList stores elements as nodes with references to next/previous nodes, supporting fast insertions/removals.
Java.what is java hashset: HashSet stores unique elements with no order, implemented using hash table for fast access.
Java.what is java hashmap: HashMap stores key-value pairs with unique keys and allows fast retrieval using hashing.
Java.what is java treemap: TreeMap stores key-value pairs in sorted order according to keys, implemented as a Red-Black tree.
Java.what is java iterator: Iterator traverses collections sequentially, supporting removal during iteration.
Java.what is java for-each loop: For-each loop iterates over elements of arrays or collections without using an index.
Java.what is java enum: Enum defines a fixed set of constants, used for representing finite state or options.
Java.what is java string: String represents a sequence of characters in Java, implemented as an immutable object.
Java.what is java stringbuilder: StringBuilder represents a mutable sequence of characters, efficient for frequent modifications.
Java.what is java stringbuffer: StringBuffer is a thread-safe, mutable sequence of characters used for multi-threaded applications.
Java.what is java equals vs == operator: Equals compares content of objects; '==' compares references (memory addresses).
Java.what is java instanceof: Instanceof checks if an object is an instance of a specific class or implements an interface.
Java.what is java recursion: Recursion is a method calling itself directly or indirectly to solve problems.
Java.what is java static method: Static method belongs to the class, not objects, and can be called without creating an instance.
Java.what is java object cloning: Cloning creates a copy of an object using the clone() method from the Cloneable interface.
Java.what is java garbage collection: Garbage collection automatically deallocates memory occupied by unreachable objects.
Java.what is java synchronized keyword: Synchronized ensures that a block or method is thread-safe, allowing only one thread at a time.
Java.what is java multithreading: Multithreading allows concurrent execution of multiple threads within a single program for efficiency.
Java.what is java runnable interface: Runnable defines a task to run on a thread, implemented via the run() method.
Java.what is java thread class: Thread class represents a thread in Java; can be subclassed to override run() method.
Java.what is java daemon thread: Daemon threads run in the background and terminate automatically when all non-daemon threads finish.
Java.what is java exception hierarchy: Java exceptions inherit from Throwable, divided into Error (system-level) and Exception (program-level).
Java.what is java serialization: Serialization converts objects into a byte stream for storage or transmission, implemented via Serializable interface.
Java.what is java deserialization: Deserialization converts a byte stream back into a copy of the original object.
Java.what is java transient keyword: Transient prevents fields from being serialized during object serialization.
Java.what is java finalizer method: Finalize() is called by garbage collector before object destruction for cleanup (deprecated in modern Java).
Java.what is java reflection: Reflection allows inspection and modification of classes, methods, and fields at runtime.
Java.what is java annotations: Annotations provide metadata about code, used by compilers or frameworks for configuration or processing.
Java.what is java generics: Generics enable type-safe classes, interfaces, and methods, preventing runtime type errors.
Java.what is java wildcards in generics: Wildcards represent unknown types in generics, e.g., ?, ? extends T, ? super T.
Java.what is java lambda expression: Lambda expressions provide concise syntax to implement functional interfaces with a single method.
Java.what is java functional interface: Functional interface has only one abstract method, used in lambda expressions.
Java.what is java streams: Streams process sequences of elements functionally, supporting filter, map, reduce, and collect operations.
Java.what is java optional class: Optional represents a container that may or may not contain a non-null value, avoiding NullPointerException.
Java.what is java nio package: NIO (New I/O) provides efficient non-blocking I/O operations for files, buffers, and channels.
Java.what is java file handling: Java file handling uses classes like File, FileReader, FileWriter, BufferedReader, and BufferedWriter for file operations.
Java.what is java socket programming: Socket programming enables communication between computers over a network using TCP/IP or UDP protocols.
Java.what is java RMI: RMI (Remote Method Invocation) allows invoking methods on objects located on different JVMs over a network.
Java.what is java JDBC: JDBC (Java Database Connectivity) allows Java programs to interact with databases using SQL queries.
Java.what is java servlet: Servlets are server-side Java programs that handle HTTP requests and generate dynamic web content.
Java.what is java JSP: JSP (JavaServer Pages) allows embedding Java code in HTML pages to create dynamic web applications.
Java.what is java MVC architecture: MVC separates an application into Model (data), View (UI), and Controller (logic), improving modularity and maintainability.
